docs.lead_paragraph: France's Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, has President Jacques Chirac and his conservative opposition all tied up in knots six months after defeating them at the polls. ''The real President these days is not Chirac, but Jospin,'' a conservative member of Parliament fumed the other day. The legislator was commenting on Mr. Jospin's ability to pick his way unscathed through the minefield of budget cuts, soaring unemployment and European fiscal policy that blasted Mr. Chirac's protege Alain Juppe out of the Prime Minister's job in the legislative elections last spring.

headline.main: Deft French Premier Unscathed by Jobless Rate

docs.abstract: Prime Min Lionel Jospin of France manages to pick his way unscathed through minefield of budget cuts, soaring unemployment and European fiscal policy that blasted Alain Juppe out of Prime Minister's job in the spring; incessantly repeats that jobs are his first priority even as he quietly continues deficit-cutting measures that made Juppe unpopular, thus keeping ratings high, to grudging admiration of his opponents; photo (M)
docs.snippet: France's Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, has President Jacques Chirac and his conservative opposition all tied up in knots six months after defeating them at the polls.     ''The real President these days is not Chirac, but Jospin,'' a...

docs.lead_paragraph: In his defense of a White House aide, Ira C. Magaziner, who has been accused by a Federal judge of giving ''misleading'' testimony in a lawsuit, President Clinton has inadvertently given Congressional Republicans a weapon to use against his nominee to a top Justice Department job. The nominee is Beth Nolan, a former deputy White House counsel whom Mr. Clinton named last summer to head the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel. The office is an important one, writing major opinions on constitutional issues.

headline.main: Clinton Defense of Aide May Hurt Nominee

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's defense of White House aide, Ira Magaziner, who was accused by Federal judge of giving misleading testimony in lawsuit related to Administration's health-care task force, may be used by Congressional Republicans as weapon against Beth Nolan, his nominee to head important Office of Legal Counsel in Justice Department; Republicans say they will make issue of her advice to Magaziner at her Senate confirmation hearings (M)
docs.snippet: In his defense of a White House aide, Ira C. Magaziner, who has been accused by a Federal judge of giving ''misleading'' testimony in a lawsuit, President Clinton has inadvertently given Congressional Republicans a weapon to use against his nominee...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, a former chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died on Monday at the Meadow Lakes Health Care Center in Hightstown, N.J. He was 88 years old and had been ailing for several years with Alzheimer's disease, said his son, Gilbert Van Ingh Fitzhugh. Mr. Fitzhugh retired in 1973 after 10 years at the helm of Met Life. While insurance was his first love -- he even met his wife, who had joined the company's London office, when her desk wound up near his at Met Life's Manhattan headquarters -- Mr. Fitzhugh also became an agent of political change. At a White House news conference in 1967, he announced the formation of a $1 billion fund in which insurance companies would invest in rehabilitating rundown urban housing.

headline.main: Gilbert Fitzhugh, 88, Dies; Ex-Metropolitan Life Chief

docs.abstract: Gilbert W Fitzhugh, former chairman and chief executive of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, dies at age 88; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The announcement by the Japanese automobile maker Toyota early this month that it would build an assembly plant employing 2,000 workers in the rust-belt town of Valenciennes in northern France seemed a hopeful omen that even a European welfare state could still be a good investment. With 3.1 million people unemployed, 12.4 percent of the labor force according to figures released today, this country needs all the jobs it can get, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's Socialist Cabinet hailed the Japanese decision as proof that neither high French labor costs nor the impending reduction of the French workweek to 35 hours were a deterrent to growth or to job creation.

headline.main: Cloudy Visibility on France's Road to Recovery

docs.abstract: Article on uncertain economic future for France; says Christmas retail-sales season just past was one of best in 90's, but also one of only few bright signs in economy stuck in vicious circle of high taxation and high unemployment; critics of Prime Min Lionel Jospin say he practically guaranteed that unemployment would stay around 12.5 percent for foreseeable future by going ahead with law that will force companies with more than 20 employees to go to 35-hour week in year 2000 without reducing salaries; whether Asian crisis and 35-hour law will dampen economy's ability to recover is only one of questions hanging over country that had begun to doubt its ability to compete in global age; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton came to the defense today of Ira C. Magaziner, a senior White House aide accused by a Federal judge of giving dishonest testimony, even as conservative groups organized to turn Mr. Magaziner into a symbol of Administration misconduct. In a written statement released late this afternoon, Mr. Clinton said: ''I am quite confident that Mr. Magaziner acted appropriately.'' He pointed to a previous investigation by a United States Attorney that found ''no basis'' to conclude that Mr. Magaziner committed a crime and ''no significant evidence'' that he had made, or even tried to make, a false statement.

headline.main: Clinton Stands By His Embattled Aide

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton defends Ira C Magaziner, senior White House aide accused by Federal judge of giving dishonest testimony in describing secret procedures used to develop President's health-care proposals in 1993; says Magaziner will remain valued member of Administration; conservative groups are organizing to turn Magaziner into symbol of Administration misconduct (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton came to the defense today of Ira C. Magaziner, a senior White House aide accused by a Federal judge of giving dishonest testimony, even as conservative groups organized to turn Mr. Magaziner into a symbol of Administration...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will soon order a major effort to locate and sign up millions of children who are eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled in the program, White House officials say. The officials said that Mr. Clinton was dismayed to find that most states had made little progress in enrolling children from low-income families in the last year.

headline.main: CLINTON ORDERING EFFORT TO SIGN UP MEDICAID CHILDREN

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will soon order major effort to locate and sign up the estimated three millions children who are eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled in program; these children make up nearly a third of nation's uninsured children; Clinton is dismayed that states have made scant progress in enrolling children from low-income families in the last year; continued failure to enroll children in Medicaid could prove politically embarrassing for Clinton, suggesting that while he campaigned for a new Children's Health Insurance Program, his Administration has not taken full advantage of existing program; graph (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton will soon order a major effort to locate and sign up millions of children who are eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled in the program, White House officials say.    The officials said that Mr. Clinton was dismayed to find that...

docs.lead_paragraph: As he sits restlessly on the edge of the sofa in his grandmother's living room in Washington Heights, his gangly limbs unemployed, it is easier to picture Alexander Hernandez, 12, speeding around his beloved basketball court than cooped up at home, where he is recovering from open-heart surgery. Grinning from ear to ear, he showed off the scar, which arched impressively around his left shoulder blade. During a routine checkup in November, Alexander's school nurse detected a heart murmur that demanded immediate investigation. But the Hernandez family, recent immigrants from Venezuela who speak no English, had no health insurance.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Helping a Boy's Heart Grow Stronger

docs.abstract: Children's Aid Society, which receives funds from New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helps family of 12-year-old boy recovering from heart surgery; photo (M)
